did.abstract: Compensation and Staff Relations division of the Personnel Office of the University of Michigan. Administrative records documenting personnel policies and procedures, records detailing negotiation and administration of the University's contract with the Graduate Employees Organization; memoranda to deans, directors and department heads; also records documenting the activities of numerous employees' unions at the university.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

did.physloc: Portions located in offsite storage; prior notification required for access.

acqinfo.p: Records were transferred from the Personnel Office (Donor No. 7384) in various accessions

accessrestrict.p: The Personnel Office records are open for research except for certain records restricted by statute or university policy. Restricted material includes personnel-related files, including search, review, promotion, and tenure files; student educational records; client/patient records; and records of executive officers of the university.

The Personnel Office record group includes restricted material in the following categories:
Personnel Related Records -- Boxes 31
Patient/Client Records -- Boxes 31

userestrict.p: Copyright is held by the Board of Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Personnel Office (University of Michigan) Records, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: The University of Michigan Personnel Office was established on January 26, 1945. The office formally reports to the Provost and Executive Vice President for Academic Affairs. Among the Personnel Office's many responsibilities are the development and implementation of the university's personnel policies, administration of the faculty promotion and tenure granting process, and negotiation and administration of contracts with unionized university employees. It also maintains the official employment record for all faculty and staff. In compliance with the Michigan Freedom of Information Act, the Personnel Office makes salary information for all university employees available to the public (The annually published salary list is located in the University of Michigan Office of Human Resources and Affirmative Action publications record group).

The Personnel Office develops and implements personnel policies for the University of Michigan. The office establishes the guidelines that govern the hiring and firing of all university staff, including academic faculty. The salary grades which determine an employee's initial compensation are based on the skills necessary to fill a position as well as previous experience relating to that position.

Recommendations for faculty promotions and granting of tenure are initiated by the department, college or school. These recommendations are transmitted through the Personnel Office to the president and provost and executive vice president for academic affairs, and then to the Board of Regents for final action.

The Personnel Office is the university's agent in labor negotiations with various staff and professional bargaining units. In the late 1950s, the University adopted a policy of neutrality with regards to employee union activities. Employees were allowed to seek union representation in grievance and other procedures. However, the university still refused to recognize any one union to speak for all employees, and thus refused to bargain collectively. At this time, the university saw an upswing in union activity, with the Association of Federal, State, and Municipal Employees (AFSCME), Local 1583, at the forefront. The Building Service Employees' International Union (BSEIU), Local 378, was also active on campus at this time.

In 1965, another surge in activity took place following the state's revision of the Hutchinson Act, recognizing the right of government employees to bargain collectively. In 1968, the Michigan Labor Mediation Board recognized the University's service and maintenance employees as an appropriate collective bargaining unit. These employees soon elected AFSCME to represent them. The first union contract signed by the university became effective September 13, 1968. The complexities of these negotiations can be seen in the events of 1970 when graduate student assistants petitioned the Michigan Employment Relations Commission (MERC) for recognition of a collective bargaining unit. The university argued that if graduate students were to be considered employees, they did not compose a bargaining unit by themselves, but rather were a component part of several larger bargaining units. Without ruling on the employment issue, MERC dismissed the student petition based on the university's second argument.
In February 1994, the Personnel Office and the Affirmative Action Office were combined into a new entity, Human Resources and Affirmative Action (HRAA).

scopecontent.p: The Personnel Office records comprise 31 linear feet and span a wide range of years from the 1940s to the early 1990s. The records document the activities of the office prior to its 1994 consolidation with the Affirmative Action Office. The office is now part of Human Resources and Affirmative Action. The records have been filed as received from the unit in periodic accessions. As such there is considerable overlap in topics covered and dates of coverage within the various records series. Files relating to specific promotion and tenure cases are in a separate record group, University of Michigan Office of Human Resources and Affirmative Action Promotion Casebooks. A finding aid for these records is available in the Bentley Library.

The records of the Personnel Office are divided into nine series: Topical Files of Assistant to the Vice President for Academic Affairs: Charles Allmand; Topical Files of Assistant Vice President for Academic Affairs-Personnel Administration: Colleen Dolan-Greene; Personnel Data Systems (PDS) Files; Graduate Student Assistants (GSA)/Graduate Employees Organization (GEO) Files; Memoranda to Deans, Directors, and Department Heads; Administrative Files, 1980-1992; Administrative Files, 1970-1994; Labor Relations, and Administrative Files, 1963-1994.

did.unittitle: Topical Files of Assistant to the Vice President for Academic Affairs

scopecontent.p: The Topical Files series originate from the offices of Assistant to the Vice President for Academic Affairs. In 1986 the title of the office was changed from Assistant to the Vice President for Academic Affairs to Assistant Vice President for Academic Affairs-Personnel Administration, although responsibilities remained the same. The series is divided into two subseries reflecting the tenure of the two individuals who held the office: Charles Allmand, 1969-1985 and Colleen Dolan Greene, 1986-1993. Both subseries reflect the wide ranging responsibilities of the Personnel Office within the University of Michigan infrastructure.

The Topical Files of Assistant to the Vice President for Academic Affairs of Charles Allmand, 1969-1985 (8.5 linear ft.) includes information on the many university divisions with personnel concerns, and information on numerous faculty and staff issues including appointment, promotion and tenure procedures.

scopecontent.p: The Topical Files of Assistant Vice President for Academic Affairs-Personnel Administration: Colleen Dolan-Greene, 1986-1993 series (5 linear ft.) contains an alphabetical run of administrative files that originated from the office of Dolan-Greene, Charles M. Allmand's successor. The series contains several folders of monthly personnel reports and data comparisons. The series also contains information detailing negotiations with unions representing university employees, tenure and promotion process, and employee salary issues.

did.unittitle: Afroamerican and African Studies, Center for (CAAS) 1970-1988

scopecontent.p: The Personnel Data Systems (PDS) Files series (1.5 linear ft.) documents Personnel Data Systems, a group responsible for incorporating data processing technologies into the system that responds to data-based information survey requests. The series consists of two subseries: a Chronological File running from 1969 to 1984, and a Topical File.

did.unittitle: 1976 (re: research change of identification away from social security number for security)
Graduate Student Assistants (GSA)/Graduate Employees Organization (GEO) Files

scopecontent.p: The Graduate Student Assistants (GSA)/Graduate Employees Organization (GEO) Files (8 linear ft.) series dates from 1949 to 1985 (primarily 1974 to 1980). The records deal with the Personnel Office's relationship with GEO and, to a limited extent, earlier attempts to unionize graduate student assistants. The material has been arranged into three sub series. The Chronological Files measure seven feet and makes up the bulk of the records. It is supplemented by a second sub series, Miscellaneous Material and a third sub series, Arbitration/Grievances.

odd.p: (Published by Personnel Office to explain the university's bargaining position)

did.unittitle: Memoranda to Deans, Directors, and Department Heads 1963-1989

scopecontent.p: Memoranda to Deans, Directors, and Department Heads (1 linear ft.), 1963-1989, principally from the office of the Assistant Vice President for Academic Affairs/Faculty Personnel Administration, are arranged chronologically by calendar year. The memos dictate university-wide personnel matters and are directed at those capable of disseminating their contents to large numbers of employees. They deal with a variety of policy and procedural issues including appointment, promotion, and compensation of faculty and graduate assistants.

Administrative Files were received in several accessions, each of which is described as a separate, chronologically bounded subseries. The inclusive dates of the subseries overlap and topics and the same topics maybe included in more than one subseries.

Administrative Files, 1980-1992 were received in 1996, and comprise 3 linear feet in volume. The files are alphabetically arranged. As with previous accessions, this series includes information on personnel concerns and faculty and staff retirement and tenure procedures. There is also general information on the Graduate Employees Organization.

did.unittitle: Statistical Reports: Personnel Head counts and Union Deductions 1960-1970

scopecontent.p: The Administrative Files, 1970-1994, are arranged alphabetically by topic or office name. Received in 1997, this subseries overlaps with the previously received administrative files series. Many of these files derive from offices within the Personnel Department, and consist primarily of monthly reports or reports and memos on specific subjects. Informative summary material on personnel activities can be found in the "Audits and Reviews," "Personnel Office--Reorganization," and "Personnel Office--Long Range Planning" files.

did.unittitle: Faculty and Staff Assistance Program (see Personnel Support and Development Program)
Family Care Resources Program (see Personnel Support and Development Program)
Human Resource Development (see Personnel Support and Development Program)

scopecontent.p: The Administrative Files, 1963-1994 are arranged alphabetically by topic or office name and cover similar date spans to the previously received administrative files. The majority of the open files relate to the business operations and organizational planning of the Office of Human Resources and Affirmative Action.

did.unittitle: Office of Administration Systems Supervisory Group 1986-1990
Personnel Audit-Center for Research on Learning and Teaching 1991-1994

scopecontent.p: The Administrative Files, 1971-1994 (2 linear feet) subseries was received in the 2005 accession. As is the case with the other Administrative File series, the files are arranged alphabetically by topic or office name. The dates also overlap with previous Administrative Files subseries.

scopecontent.p: The Labor Relations series is a rich source of information concerning the numerous unions on campus, their attempts to organize employees, and their demands on behalf of members. The series also documents the reactions and tactics of the Personnel Department staff and other university administrators. The subseries "History of Labor Relations at the University of Michigan" records the university's official stance towards unions from the late 1930s to the early 1970s, with emphasis on the 1960s. Within this subseries, The "Regents' Meetings Personnel Policies, 1937-1967" file is a useful summary, excerpting from the minutes of the board those decisions which affected labor relations or personnel policy. This subseries also documents the administration's reaction to the Hutchinson Act of 1965, and the subsequent upswing in union activity.

The rest of the series is arranged alphabetically, and consists of files which correspond to specific unions, or specific groups of employees and their attempts to organize. Of special interest is the file relating to the Student Employees' Association and the file entitled "Faculty Unions". Activities of the Association of Federal, State, County, and Municipal Employees (AFSCME), Local 1583, are well documented for the years 1958 to 1968, especially 1958 to 1961. The union made demands on behalf of its entire membership, as well as on behalf of individual employees with specific grievances. The Personnel Office also collected fliers and news clippings related to this union. Relations with the Building Service Employees' International Union (BSEIU), Local 378 are documented from 1966 to 1968. However, files covering the years 1949 to 1966 were destroyed in 1968. In 1970, the Teamster's Union challenged AFSCME for right to represent service and maintenance employees, and the file "Teamsters' Organizing Drive" documents this event.
